results.title: Hitler: revenge to ruin
results.creator_credit: Nielsen-Ferns, New York Times Productions and Don Thompson
results.brief_description: This film documents those events during World War II that gradually led to Hitler’s fall from power and eventual suicide inthe face of defeat. Shows Hitler at the apex of his power in 1940. With the defeat of France, Hitler was not content to stop his drive for control of Europe. Narrated by Henry Fonda. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Hitler: anatomy of a dicatatorship
results.brief_description: Adolph Hitler became legal head of the German government in 1933. To a nation torn by economic, political and spiritual crises, he promised strong leadership and a policy of revenge against supposed enemies, at home and abroad. With little opposition, Hitler soon made himself the master of Europe. Before the Allies finally defeated him, he would be responsible for the deaths of over 350 million people, an unmatched record of dictatorial brutality. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Hitler: a film from Germany = Hitler, Ein Film Aus Deutschland
results.creator_credit: TMS Film GmbH, Solaris Film, EDR, I N A, BBC and Hans Syberberg
results.brief_description: In confronting Nazism Syberberg was not interested in the conventions of realism. In Syberberg’s view, ‘one doesn’t fight Hitler with the statistics of Auschwitz and the sociology of his economic system, but with Richard Wagner and Mozart’. In a series of surrealist tableaux in a variety of dramatic modes - fairytale, circus, morality play, allegorical pageant, magic ceremony, philosophical dialogue - in four parts, Syberberg seeks to embrace, in the words of John Sandford, ‘the mythic totality of Hitler’s world (‘pathos’) and the confrontation of the mythic with reality (‘irony’), the sublime with the ridiculous’. For Susan Sontag ‘it is a ghostly film haunted by (Syberberg’s) great cinematic models (Melies, Eisenstein) and antimodels (Riefenstahl, Hollywood), by German Romanticism (and) above all by Wagner and his music’. Contents: Der gral The grail (96 min.)—A German dream Ein Deutscher Traun (126 min.)—The end of a winter’s tale and the final victory of progress Das ende eines wintermarchens (93 min.)—We children of hell remember the European age Wir kinder der holle (100 min.) Also includes the book ‘Syberberg, A filmmaker from Germany’. In German and English with English subtitles.

constellations_other.name: Undercutting extremism with absurdity
constellations_other.description: Taika Waititi's satirical performance as Adolf Hitler in Jojo Rabbit connects to a number of other portrayals that includes ill-fated (and conceived) TV shows, memes, high camp and cinema classics.

results.title: Hitler's challenge
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “History 1917-1967”.
Describes German re-armament, changes in foreign policy, the failure of appeasement, and initial successes of the Blitzkrieg. Presented by Brian Redhead.

results.title: Hitchhiker's guide to the galaxy. - Volume 1.
results.brief_description: This is the story of the Hitchhiker’s guide to the galaxy. Perhaps the most remarkable - certainly the most successful - book ever to come out of the great publishing corporations of Ursa Minor. The story of Arthur Dent, a seemingly normal Englishman whose ordinary life suddenly takes a startling turn one Thursday. A Thursday which becomes steadily more extraordinary when his buddy Ford Prefect imparts the terrible, hideous news: He’s not from Earth and the Earth’s going to be demolished in 12 minutes to make way for a new hyperspace bypass! This program brings to life once more the magic of the cult TV series.

results.title: Hitchcock at war: Aventure malgache. Bon voyage
results.creator_credit: Pheonix Films, Alfred Hitchcock, Angus MacPhail and J Orton
results.brief_description: Having just completed work on ‘Lifeboat’ in Hollywood, Hitchcock returned to the UK keen to contribute to the war effort. He made these two short films for the Ministry of Information, for use solely as propaganda tools for the French Resistance. ‘Bon Voyage’: might almost fit in as an episode for Hitchcock’s later TV series. A Scottish air gunner who has escaped from a POW camp in Germany and made it safely back to Britain, is being questioned by a Free French intelligence officer. As he explains how he was helped and guided by a Polish fellow-escapee, we watch (in flashback) the perilous last stages of his journey through France, passed from hand to hand by ambivalent strangers through a series of sinister rendez-vous that - he hopes - adds up to an underground Resistance network. ‘Aventure malgache’: Paris’ Moliere Players enact a thrilling tale of the French Resistance. The fact-based story concerns Claurousse, who boldly operated on behalf of the Underground in Nazi-occupied Madagascar. Sent to prison by the Vichy government, Claurousse is rescued by the British, and is thus able to continue tweaking Hitler’s nose. As in his previous ‘Murder’ and his later ‘Stage Fright’, Hitchcock seems delighted with the opportunity to combine the specialized world of the theater with the more treacherous terrain of intrigue. The film was made, as Hitchcock later told Francois Truffaut, to expound the inner conflicts which divided the Free French, and which had become apparent during script conferences. The most interesting aspect of ‘Aventure Malgache’ lies now in its typically Hitchcockian element of masquerade. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Hitch hiker
results.creator_credit: CPC Productions, Polly Turner and Gerald Varney
results.brief_description: Young hitchhikers are interviewed and we hear their philosophy regarding hitchhiking. We hear their poetry, see them camping amid spectacular scenery and meet the people who are willing to pick them up. This activity is seen as a rebellion to parental authority and a statement of individualism.
